name: Buenos Aires
info: Argentina’s most populated province and the country’s main economic engine.
history: Originally inhabited by indigenous peoples such as the Querandí, the region became Argentina’s political and economic core after the city’s foundation in 1580.
relevantData: The Port of Buenos Aires played a central role in foreign trade during the 19th and 20th centuries.
geography: Vast fertile plains dominate the province, with Atlantic coastline and low mountain systems.

touristSites.name: Plaza de Mayo
touristSites.description: It is the historical and civic heart of Buenos Aires, surrounded by the Casa Rosada, the colonial Cabildo, and the Metropolitan Cathedral, and has been the setting for key events in Argentine history.

touristSites.name: The Obelisk
touristSites.description: Located on Avenida 9 de Julio, it is the city’s most recognized icon, built to commemorate the fourth centenary of the founding of Buenos Aires and offering panoramic views of the city.

touristSites.name: La Boca
touristSites.description: A colorful riverside neighborhood, it stands out for its tenement houses painted in vibrant colors, especially along Caminito, an open-air museum featuring street art, tango shows, and handicrafts.

touristSites.name: Puerto Madero
touristSites.description: It is the result of the reconversion of former docks into an elegant neighborhood with modern architecture, highlighted by the Puente de la Mujer, designed by Santiago Calatrava and symbolizing a couple dancing the tango.

touristSites.name: Recoleta Cemetery
touristSites.description: The Recoleta Cemetery is an iconic funerary monument in Buenos Aires, renowned for its artistic and historical value. Its main entrance features a portico formed by four Greek Doric columns, completed during a renovation in 1881. The exterior and interior pediments are adorned with Latin inscriptions: 'Requiescant in pace' (May they rest in peace) on the exterior, and 'Expectamus Dominum' (We await the Lord) on the interior, symbolizing the dialog between the living and the dead.

name: Catamarca
info: Mountainous and arid province with a strong cultural identity and mining tradition.
history: Founded in 1683, Catamarca preserved strong indigenous and colonial traditions and has long been linked to regional mining activities.
relevantData: It is one of Argentina’s main lithium-producing provinces.
geography: The landscape is dominated by mountain ranges, valleys and desert areas with sparse population.
capital: San Fernando del Valle de Catamarca

touristSites.name: San Fernando del Valle de Catamarca
touristSites.description: It is the capital and an ideal starting point for exploring the province, notable for its historic center with colonial buildings, the Cathedral Basilica of Our Lady of the Valley, and cultural events such as the National Poncho Festival.

touristSites.name: Cuesta del Portezuelo
touristSites.description: It is one of the most iconic routes, with 20 kilometers of hairpin turns connecting the capital to high-altitude areas, offering stunning viewpoints and opportunities for paragliding and trekking.

touristSites.name: Fiambalá
touristSites.description: It stands out for its hot springs, considered therapeutic and relaxing, with temperatures between 28 and 52°C, as well as for being the starting point of the Route of the Six-Thousanders and for its astronomical activities thanks to its clear skies.

touristSites.name: Shincal Ruins
touristSites.description: They are an Inca archeological site located in the southern part of the province, with cobblestone streets and the remains of buildings that reveal the sophisticated engineering of this ancient civilization.

touristSites.name: Pumice Stone Field (Campo de Piedra Pómez)
touristSites.description: n Antofagasta de las Sierras, it’s a unique landscape of white and pink rock formations sculpted by the wind, accessible only by 4×4 or on an organized tour, and considered one of the Puna’s most impressive natural treasures.

name: Chaco
info: Warm-climate province with strong agro-industrial development.
history: Chaco was incorporated late into the Argentine state and developed mainly through agricultural and forestry expansion in the late 19th century.
relevantData: It is one of Argentina’s main cotton-producing provinces.
geography: Flat terrain predominates, covered by native forests of the Gran Chaco region.

touristSites.name: Resistencia
touristSites.description: It is the capital of the province and an unmissable destination, known as the City of Sculptures for its hundreds of works scattered throughout the downtown area. The Sculpture Museum at its heart, spanning 15,000 square meters, houses an extensive collection of contemporary art.

touristSites.name: El Impenetrable National Park
touristSites.description: The largest in northern Argentina, spanning 130,000 hectares, it is an international ecotourism benchmark. It offers hiking, horseback riding, birdwatching, and community-based tourism in places like Misión Nueva Pompeya and Villa Río Bermejito, where you can enjoy warm beaches and water activities.

touristSites.name: Isla del Cerrito
touristSites.description: Located at the confluence of the Paraguay and Paraná Rivers, this 12,000-hectare island offers white-sand beaches, bluffs, lush vegetation, and activities such as sport fishing, boating, and photo safaris. It has campsites, guesthouses, and a historical museum about the War of the Triple Alliance.

touristSites.name: Chaco National Park
touristSites.description: Located 120 km from Resistencia, it features savannas, lagoons, and marshes, home to species such as quebracho trees, tapirs, anteaters, and over 340 species of birds. It’s ideal for camping, hiking trails, and enjoying nature in its purest form.

touristSites.name: Los Chaguares Nature Reserve
touristSites.description: Just 20 km from Resistencia, it features 19 hectares of native forest, three trails, and an Interpretation Center where you can learn about the local flora and fauna. It’s the perfect place for a nearby, peaceful getaway.

name: Chubut
info: Patagonian province known for its marine wildlife and strong Welsh cultural heritage.
history: Chubut received significant Welsh immigration beginning in 1865, leaving a distinctive cultural legacy that remains visible today.
relevantData: Península Valdés is a UNESCO Natural World Heritage Site.
geography: The landscape is dominated by Patagonian plateaus, with Atlantic coastline and Andean regions in the west.

touristSites.name: Puerto Madryn
touristSites.description: It stands out as one of Chubut’s most popular tourist destinations, known for its connection to the history of the southern right whale and as a starting point for visiting the Valdés Peninsula, a natural site of global importance.

touristSites.name: Península Valdés
touristSites.description: It is a key destination for whale, penguin, sea lion, and elephant seal watching, and is inscribed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site for its extraordinary biodiversity.

touristSites.name: Punta Tombo
touristSites.description: Located south of Puerto Madryn, it is home to the world’s largest Magellanic penguin colony, with nearly one million birds, and is an essential attraction for nature lovers.

touristSites.name: Los Alerces National Park
touristSites.description: Declared a World Heritage Site in 2017, it offers impressive forests of ancient alerce trees, crystal-clear lakes, and hiking trails, making it a privileged destination in the Andes.

touristSites.name: Esquel
touristSites.description: A city in the mountain region, it combines a rich Welsh heritage with a solid tourism infrastructure, and serves as a gateway to Los Alerces National Park and nearby towns such as Trevelin, with their unique traditions and landscapes.

name: Córdoba
info: Province located in the heart of Argentina, known for its historical, educational and industrial importance.
history: Founded in 1573 by Jerónimo Luis de Cabrera, Córdoba was a strategic center of the Viceroyalty of the Río de la Plata. It hosts the National University of Córdoba, founded in 1613.
relevantData: Córdoba was the birthplace of the 1918 University Reform, which transformed higher education across Latin America.
geography: The province combines fertile plains with mountain ranges that create valleys and diverse microclimates.

touristSites.name: Córdoba Capital
touristSites.description: It stands out for its historic center, where the Jesuit Block—a UNESCO World Heritage Site—is located, along with the Cathedral, the Cabildo (City Hall), and the National University.

touristSites.name: Capilla del Monte
touristSites.description: Known for its one-of-a-kind covered avenue and the legend of Cerro Uritorco, surrounded by tales of sightings and extraterrestrial phenomena. Perfect for trekking, visiting its waterfalls, and exploring its mystical atmosphere.

touristSites.name: Villa Carlos Paz
touristSites.description: The province’s premier destination, with its iconic cuckoo clock, the San Roque Dam, and a vibrant nightlife featuring theaters, casinos, and water activities. Ideal for entertainment and panoramic views.

touristSites.name: Mina Clavero
touristSites.description: Ideal destinations for outdoor activities, with natural river beaches like those on the Panaholma River, activities such as ATV riding and paragliding, and visits to museums like the Rocsen Museum in Nono.

touristSites.name: La Cumbrecita
touristSites.description: An alpine pedestrian village at 1,450 meters above sea level, featuring German architecture, cobblestone streets, waterfalls, and family-friendly trails. Ideal for unwinding, ziplining, or enjoying its German and Austrian cuisine.

name: Corrientes
info: Province with strong cultural identity, chamamé music and vast wetlands.
history: Founded in 1588, Corrientes maintained a strong federal identity and played an active role in Argentina’s political history.
relevantData: The Iberá Wetlands are among the most important ecosystems in South America.
geography: The landscape is dominated by plains, wetlands and the influence of the Paraná and Uruguay rivers.

touristSites.name: Iberá Wetlands
touristSites.description: One of the world’s most important wetlands, ideal for ecotourism, wildlife viewing (including iconic species such as the jaguar), boat tours, and guided hikes.

touristSites.name: Corrientes Riverside (Costanera)
touristSites.description: Officially named Costanera General San Martín, it is a promenade along the Paraná River that combines natural beauty, culture, local cuisine (such as surubí and dorado), and recreational activities.

touristSites.name: General Manuel Belgrano Bridge
touristSites.description: One of the longest bridges in the country, spanning 2.5 km, connects Corrientes with Resistencia (Chaco), renowned for its architecture and strategic importance.

touristSites.name: Corrientes Cathedral
touristSites.description: Known as the Church of Our Lady of the Rosary, it is one of the city’s oldest and most iconic buildings, boasting rich architecture and great historical and religious significance.

touristSites.name: Paso de la Patria
touristSites.description: Popular destination with beaches, a relaxed atmosphere, and excellent opportunities for water sports and sport fishing, especially for dorado and surubí.

name: Entre Ríos
info: Mesopotamian province characterized by rivers, thermal resorts and a strong federal identity.
history: Entre Ríos was a stronghold of Argentine federalism and the home of Justo José de Urquiza, a key figure in national organization.
relevantData: The Argentine Confederation was based in Paraná between 1854 and 1861.
geography: Located between the Paraná and Uruguay rivers, the province features flat terrain and numerous wetlands.

touristSites.name: Gualeguaychú
touristSites.description: It stands out for its vibrant Carnival, its beaches along the Uruguay River and its waterfront promenade, as well as the San Martín International Bridge that connects it to Fray Bentos (Uruguay).

touristSites.name: Colón
touristSites.description: It is known for its proximity to El Palmar National Park, a natural icon with yatay palm trees up to 800 years old, and its extensive 7-km waterfront promenade.

touristSites.name: Concepción del Uruguay
touristSites.description: It houses the San José Palace, the former residence of General Justo José de Urquiza, and the Monument to General Urquiza, in a park overlooking the river.

touristSites.name: Concordia
touristSites.description: It stands out for the ruins of San Carlos Castle, an ancient palace with marble staircases and weathered walls, and the impressive Salto Grande Dam.

touristSites.name: Federación
touristSites.description: It offers the modern Las Garzas Thermal Complex, with a water park, slides, and wave pools, ideal for relaxing and enjoying thermal waters.

name: Formosa
info: Border province characterized by rivers and cultural diversity.
history: Founded in 1879, Formosa consolidated its provincial status in the mid-20th century, shaped by the presence of indigenous communities.
relevantData: The province is home to indigenous groups such as the Wichí, Qom and Pilagá.
geography: Mostly flat territory crossed by major rivers like the Pilcomayo and Paraguay, with a warm climate.

touristSites.name: Río Pilcomayo National Park
touristSites.description: One of Formosa’s main tourist attractions, this national park is home to over 300 bird species, as well as mammals and a rich flora. The recreation areas at Laguna Blanca and Esteros Poi stand out, ideal for hiking, wildlife watching, and enjoying unique sunsets at the Vertedero and Fortín La Soledad.

touristSites.name: Bañado La Estrella
touristSites.description: This natural complex, located 45 km from Las Lomitas, is perfect for experiences in touch with nature. It offers photo safaris, boat trips on its waters, guided tours of indigenous and Creole communities, and the chance to enjoy unique sunsets at the Vertedero and Fortín La Soledad.

touristSites.name: Formosa Waterfront
touristSites.description: The provincial capital’s most iconic riverfront promenade, ideal for walking, watching the Paraguay River, and enjoying the Dancing Waters show—a fountain with lights and music that operates at specific times.

touristSites.name: Campo La Carmela
touristSites.description: A charming establishment on the outskirts of Formosa, known for its hospitality, dreamy sunsets, and rural experiences such as horseback riding, traditional meals, and immersion in nature. Ideal for couples and families.

touristSites.name: Formosa Nature Reserve
touristSites.description: Located in the southwestern part of the province, this reserve offers guided hikes, viewpoints with panoramic river views, and an ideal setting for observing local flora and fauna, especially at sunrise or sunset.

name: Jujuy
info: Andean province known for its cultural diversity, high-altitude landscapes and strong indigenous heritage.
history: Jujuy was originally inhabited by indigenous peoples such as the Omaguaca and Atacama. During the independence process, it played a crucial role through the Jujuy Exodus of 1812, led by Manuel Belgrano.
relevantData: The Quebrada de Humahuaca is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
geography: The province features a wide variety of landscapes including the Puna plateau, the Quebrada de Humahuaca and the Yungas rainforest.

touristSites.name: Humahuaca Ravine
touristSites.description: Recognized as a UNESCO World Heritage Site, this vast region stands out for its impressive multicolored mountains, villages with an ancient history, and landscapes that change with the sunlight. It is a key destination for those seeking culture, history, and nature.

touristSites.name: Purmamarca
touristSites.description: Known for the Hill of Seven Colors, a geological formation that displays a palette of hues that vary with the time of day. It’s an ideal place for photography, hiking, and enjoying local crafts.

touristSites.name: Tilcara
touristSites.description: Located in the heart of the Quebrada, it is a charming town with deep cultural roots. Its main attraction is the Pucará de Tilcara, a pre-Hispanic fortress of pre-Inca origin, and the Dr. Eduardo Casanova Archeological Museum, which houses a rich collection of pre-Hispanic artifacts.

touristSites.name: Salinas Grandes
touristSites.description: One of the world’s largest salt flats, located in the Puna region of Jujuy. During the rainy season, a mirror of water forms that reflects the sky, creating a surreal landscape. Ideal for adventure activities and archeological exploration.

touristSites.name: Calilegua National Park
touristSites.description: A true natural paradise in the Yungas region, with subtropical rainforest, rivers, exotic birds, and hiking trails. It’s the perfect place for those seeking to connect with nature, observe wildlife, and find tranquility.

name: La Pampa
info: Province of vast plains and strong rural tradition, located in central Argentina.
history: Originally inhabited by Ranquel indigenous peoples, La Pampa was incorporated into the Argentine state in the late 19th century and became a province in 1951.
relevantData: Livestock farming, especially cattle breeding, is the main economic activity.
geography: The landscape is dominated by semi-arid plains, with low mountain ranges in the west.

touristSites.name: Parque Luro Provincial Reserve
touristSites.description: The most visited destination, located 35 km from Santa Rosa. It stands out for its caldén forest, self-guided trails, birdwatching (over 160 species), deer rutting (March–April), and the historic main house of Pedro Luro’s estancia, now a museum.

touristSites.name: Guatraché Lagoon
touristSites.description: Located in the southeast of the province, it is a key destination for regional tourism. Ideal for camping, boat trips, birdwatching, mud therapy, and activities on the salt lagoon.

touristSites.name: Lihué Calel National Park
touristSites.description: The only national park in La Pampa, located 120 km from General Acha. It offers hiking trails, guanaco, puma, and fox watching, and 1,500-year-old rock paintings in the Valle de las Pinturas. Ideal in spring and autumn.

touristSites.name: Bernardo Larroudé Thermal Baths
touristSites.description: Located on National Route 188, they are a benchmark for thermal tourism. They offer thermal water pools, massages, mud therapy, cabins, a restaurant, and recreational activities.

touristSites.name: Casa de Piedra (Tourist Village)
touristSites.description: Renowned for its tourism development, this town offers beaches, water activities, and the Pampeano Regional Market. It attracts tourists from all over the country, especially for its wine tourism and artisanal products.

name: La Rioja
info: Province with a strong federal tradition and mountainous landscapes.
history: La Rioja was a stronghold of Argentine federalism, closely linked to the figure of Facundo Quiroga during the 19th-century civil wars.
relevantData: The province has significant wine and olive oil production.
geography: It features mountain ranges, valleys and arid climates with strong thermal amplitude.

name: Mendoza
info: International wine capital and home to Mount Aconcagua, the highest mountain in the Americas.
history: Founded in 1561 by Pedro del Castillo, Mendoza developed as a strategic stop on the commercial route across the Andes. Its irrigation system of canals, inherited from the Huarpes indigenous people, enabled agriculture in a desert environment.
relevantData: The province played a fundamental role in South American independence, serving as the base of the Army of the Andes led by General José de San Martín before crossing the Andes in 1817.
geography: Located at the foothills of the Andes mountain range, Mendoza has an arid continental climate. Its artificial oases are formed by the Mendoza, Tunuyán, Diamante and Atuel rivers.

name: Misiones
info: Subtropical province known for its rainforest and the Iguazú Falls.
history: Misiones was strongly influenced by Jesuit-Guaraní missions during the 17th and 18th centuries, leaving a unique cultural and architectural legacy.
relevantData: Iguazú Falls are one of the New Seven Wonders of Nature.
geography: Rolling hills, dense rainforest, red soils and a humid subtropical climate define the province.

name: Neuquén
info: Patagonian province that plays a key role in Argentina’s energy production.
history: Neuquén experienced strong development during the 20th century due to oil and gas exploitation. Its strategic importance increased significantly with the discovery of the Vaca Muerta formation.
relevantData: Vaca Muerta is one of the largest unconventional hydrocarbon reserves in the world.
geography: The province features Andean mountains, glacial lakes and Patagonian steppe, crossed by major rivers such as the Limay and Neuquén.

name: Río Negro
info: Diverse province combining mountains, productive valleys and Atlantic coastline.
history: Río Negro was part of the National Territory of Patagonia until it became a province in 1955. Its development has been closely linked to fruit production in the Upper Valley.
relevantData: It is one of Argentina’s main producers of apples and pears.
geography: The territory includes the Andes, irrigated valleys, plateaus and an extensive Atlantic coast.

name: Salta
info: Province rich in history and culture, widely known as 'Salta the Beautiful'.
history: Founded in 1582, Salta was a strategic stronghold during the wars of independence under the leadership of Martín Miguel de Güemes.
relevantData: General Güemes organized the Gaucho War, which was key in stopping royalist advances from Upper Peru.
geography: Its territory combines fertile valleys, Yungas rainforest and high mountain regions.

name: San Juan
info: Andean province known for mining, wine production and high solar energy potential.
history: Founded in 1562, San Juan is the birthplace of Domingo Faustino Sarmiento, one of the most influential figures in Argentine history. Major earthquakes shaped its modern urban design.
relevantData: San Juan is one of Argentina’s leading mining provinces and a national reference in solar energy development.
geography: The landscape is predominantly mountainous and arid, with irrigated valleys concentrating agricultural activity.

name: San Luis
info: Province located between the Pampas and Cuyo regions, noted for institutional stability and technological development.
history: Founded in 1594, San Luis served as a key connection point between the Andean region and central Argentina during colonial times.
relevantData: In recent decades, the province has stood out for innovation policies, digital connectivity and urban planning.
geography: It features plains, valleys and mountain ranges, including the Sierras of San Luis and Comechingones.

name: Santa Cruz
info: Southern province characterized by glaciers and vast, rugged landscapes.
history: Santa Cruz remained a national territory until 1957. Its historical development was driven by sheep farming and later by oil production.
relevantData: Los Glaciares National Park is home to the famous Perito Moreno Glacier.
geography: It features steppe landscapes, plateaus, Andean mountain ranges and strong prevailing winds.

name: Santa Fe
info: Key province for Argentina’s economy due to its agro-industrial production and strategic river ports.
history: Founded in 1573, Santa Fe hosted the Constitutional Convention of 1853 where Argentina’s National Constitution was enacted.
relevantData: Its port complex is one of the most important in the country for grain exports.
geography: Flat pampas dominate the landscape, strongly influenced by the Paraná River and extensive wetlands.

name: Santiago del Estero
info: Argentina’s oldest province, known as the 'Mother of Cities'.
history: Founded in 1553, it was the first stable Spanish settlement in what is now Argentina and the starting point for other colonial cities.
relevantData: The province is considered the cradle of Argentine folklore.
geography: Mostly flat terrain with a hot and dry climate, crossed by the Dulce and Salado rivers.

name: Tierra del Fuego
info: Argentina’s southernmost province, widely known as the End of the World.
history: Provincialized in 1990, Tierra del Fuego developed late, shaped by navigation, electronics manufacturing and Argentina’s Antarctic presence.
relevantData: The province exercises sovereignty over the Argentine Antarctic Sector.
geography: It combines mountains, subantarctic forests and rugged coastlines, with a cold and windy climate.

name: Tucumán
info: Argentina’s smallest province and the birthplace of national independence.
history: Argentina’s independence was declared in Tucumán on July 9, 1816. Since colonial times, the province has been an important agricultural and sugar-producing center.
relevantData: The Historic House of Independence is one of the country’s most important national monuments.
geography: It features plains, mountain ranges and Yungas rainforest, creating a more humid climate than the rest of the NOA region.
